Award.AwardTitle: The Genetic Basis of Phenotypic Plasticity in Meiotic Recombination Rate

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In eukaryotes such as animals and plants, physical exchange (recombination) between chromosomes during production of gametes can produce novel sets of genetic information, thus yielding new and potentially useful traits. The goal of this project is to understand how certain environmental conditions affect the rate of recombination and, ultimately, the acquisition of new traits. These studies may lead to novel strategies for breeding in agricultural settings, since the goal of such strategies is to produce plants and animals with new and beneficial traits. The project will provide hands-on research training of future scientists, including a graduate student and number of high school students during the summers. In addition, this project will serve as a launching point for presentations to local K-12 schools to promote understanding of genetics and evolution and to spark enthusiasm for scientific inquiry.

Phenotypic plasticity, the capacity of a single genotype to produce different phenotypes in different environments, is pervasive in nature. In spite of its ubiquity the genetic and molecular bases of phenotypic plasticity remain unknown. In particular, the extent to which genes underlying individual traits are the same genes underlying phenotypic plasticity in those traits remains controversial, in part because there are precious few examples for which the underlying genetic architecture of both the trait and any associated plasticity in that trait have been clearly worked out. Recombination rate is an important example of a plastic phenotype. Using meiotic recombination rate as a prototypical plastic trait, this project will test the hypothesis that phenotypic plasticity for a trait is mediated by the same genes underlying population-level variation in that trait. Using Drosophila melanogaster as the genetic model, experiments will include sequencing whole genomes, characterizing which genes are expressed and in what amounts, and association mapping to discover relationships of genotypes to phenotypes. The experiments will provide two sets of data, one identifying genetic loci associated with within-organism variation in recombination rate and the other identifying genetic loci associated with between-population variation in recombination rate. If the same loci are identified in the two data sets, this result would provide important new insights into the genetic basis of phenotypic plasticity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The genetic architecture of recombination rate variation has been aggressively pursued in a variety of organisms. In mammals, the primary finding to date that is that recombination rate variation is mediated by a small number of loci of moderate effect. These loci are consistently identified across populations and species. Moreover, at least in humans, recombination rate is correlated across the chromosomes, which is consistent with a small number of loci controlling global recombination rate. 

Our work, in contrast, shows that the genetic architecture of this trait in Drosophila is dramatically different. We find no correlation in recombination rate between the two chromosomes surveyed, and accordingly, find that the genetic loci that associate with recombination rate variation on the two chromosomes are largely non-overlapping. Another major emergent difference between our findings and what has been reported in other systems is that recombination appears to be controlled by a number of loci of very small effect. The contrast between Drosophila and mammals illustrates that though recombination rate variation is pervasive in natural populations, how this phenotypic variation arises from genetic variation may differ wildly between systems.  

Our work also informs a long-standing controversy in the field of phenotypic plasticity. Phenotypic plasticity can provide individuals with increased tolerance to environmental conditions and thus, loci that enable plasticity in a particular trait may be favored by natural selection, particularly in heterogeneous environments. Although loci encoding plasticity have long been thought to provide adaptive potential, the genetic architecture underlying phenotypic plasticity remains unknown. What types of genes enable phenotypic plasticity? Are there master ‘plasticity’ genes or is plasticity in a given phenotype governed by the same genes that determine that phenotype? Our results clearly show that together, the genes underlying phenotypic plasticity in recombination rate do not also mediate population-level variation in recombination rate. 

 

Lastly, we used whole genome sequencing of experimentally-evolved lines to identify regions underlying population-level divergence in recombination rate. We have shown that genetic variation underlying divergence in recombination between populations is the same genetic variation that underlies within population divergence in recombination rate. This is a novel finding. 

 

Our work has also contributed to the development of information infrastructure. One outcome of the completed work is that we have generated additional phenotype data for all of the lines in the DGRP. This panel of lines was designed as a community resource, such that a suite of traits could be assayed in the same set of strains by independent researchers. Among other things, this enables us to ask whether certain phenotypes are correlated with other phenotypes, which could generate new hypotheses regarding life-history tradeoffs, pleiotropy, and many other aspects of genetics and organismal biology. Another such outcome is the generation of the full genome sequences of the experimental evolution lines. These data are publically availablet. This panel of flies has been used to study the evolution of other traits, and thus the whole genome sequences we have generated can be leveraged by other researchers for their own research purposes.
